questions.question_text:
A security architect is determining the best solution for a new project. The project is developing a new intranet with advanced authentication capabilities, SSO for users, and automated provisioning to streamline Day 1 access to systems. The security architect has identified the following requirements:
1. Information should be sourced from the trusted master data source.
2. There must be future requirements for identity proofing of devices and users.
3. A generic identity connector that can be reused must be developed.
4. The current project scope is for internally hosted applications only.
Which of the following solution building blocks should the security architect use to BEST meet the requirements?

discussion.content: Just because I forgot and need to review acronyms, SPML = Service Provisioning Markup Language
The answer to this strange question is B, if anyone is on the fence about A, OAuth doesn't meet the requirements to be used in this use case, so it can't be A. I'm sticking with B.

I second your assessment. I have a similar situation in my recent experience. Intranet, diff locations, internal apps. You could choose an Ad group to gain access to the app connected by SPML with supports directory based auth. I would choose B

In large environments, where personnel must access an array of systems, SPML can provide an automated means to provide access.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an external pressure that causes companies to hire security assessors and penetration testers?

discussion.content:

Looks like I was wrong: "PCI DSS (Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard) Requirements 6.6, 11.3.1 and 11.3.2 state that penetration testing must be performed at least annually and after any significant changes â€“ for example, infrastructure or application upgrades or modifications, or after installing new system components."
https://www.itgovernanceusa.com/pcidss-and-penetration-testing

Maybe: A. Lack of adequate in-house testing skills?

questions.question_text:
Engineers at a company believe a certain type of data should be protected from competitors, but the data owner insists the information is not sensitive. An information security engineer is implementing controls to secure the corporate SAN. The controls require dividing data into four groups: non-sensitive, sensitive but accessible, sensitive but export-controlled, and extremely sensitive.
Which of the following actions should the engineer take regarding the data?

discussion.content: The SCAP scanners I've seen do not output enabled or disabled. They show the scan it's doing "say for password complexity" then a "pass" or "fail". I'll be going with A if I see this on the exam.

comments.content:
I am not sure if this webpage is referring to a particular SCAP, or any SCAP. 
Supposedly, a SCAP rule can have nine result states: Pass, Fail, Error, Unknown, Not applicable, Not checked, Not selected, Informational, Fixed. 
Note: that list does not include: Enabled, Disabled
https://docs.bmc.com/docs/ServerAutomation/88/scap-rule-result-states-623577160.html

Actually, the "output" in the question almost looks like SCAP settings, as opposed to SCAP output. 
For example, when you set up a scan, if you don't want to check password complexity, you would set: "Password complexity Disabled"
http://my.saintcorporation.com/resources/documentation/help/saint9_help/scap_support.htm

discussion.content: Given answer is correct. SCAP scanner output doesn't look this way.

Doesn't SCAP output usually give a numerical score? For example:
 Password strength 87%
Isn't SCAP a type of vulnerability scanner?

comments.content: This output doesn't look like SCAP output either. I don't think a vulnerability scanner has to be an external tool. I think there are vulnerability scanners that can do INTERNAL and CREDENTIALED scans.

discussion.content:
I agree that B is the answer.
This output doesn't look like vulnerability scanner output, which would be from an external tool (I'm not sure a VS can pick up whether or not password complexity is enabled). This output suggests an INTERNAL and CREDENTIALED scan, which would mean it has to be a SCAP scanner.

I think that B is better.
The purpose of a security content automation protocol (SCAP) scanner is to apply an already-accepted security standard to organizations that donâ€™t currently have one, or to those that have weak implementations of security standards. SCAP allows security administrators to scan computers, software, and other devices based on a predetermined security baseline in order to determine how the configuration and software patches that are implemented compare to the baseline standard. The National Vulnerability Database (NVD) is the United States government content repository for SCAP.
I guess C makes sense over social engineering, since NDAs are quite important, and policy could always include social engineering technique warnings.
